answers.answer: Hi.Is his diabetes adequately controlled?Diabetic neuropathy can occur in many forms. If it affects the cranial nerves, it is called cranial neuropathy. There is a possibility that diabetes has affected cranial nerves I, IX and X which could explain the distorted taste and smell.You should bring him to a physician to help manage his condition.Good luck.

Hello.Although an uncontrolled Diabetic Neuropathy appears to be probable here, there is always a possibility of Alzheimer's disease. The age points towards it. Usually the smell goes first.It would thus be a good step to get an additional neuropsychological work-up done.Regards

question: What could be the cause of distorted taste and smell leading to the aversion of most foods in a 70 year old man with diabetes? He is an insulin dependent diabetic.  He has also  been experiencing severe pain in his left leg.  So far negative for blood clots, negative bone scan, no change in medications other than being given Percocet for the pain in the leg.  He previously enjoyed eating, but in the past few months has not been able to eat much meat, cheese, peanut butter, eggs, almost anything he tries to eat smells and tastes rotten. It's getting very hard to find something he will eat.  Has been losing a lot of weight.  Could there be neuropathy involved?  Would appreciate any help in directing us in the right direction.
title: Distorted taste and smell
